div1.p: [Rojas?] gives a history of the San Jose property, a probable site of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Notes on the San Jose property [by Maria Teresa Loma viuda de Rojas?], [1940]
div1.p:
Paragraph 53: The property San Jose was sold to Mr. Dino
Francisco Pogolotti on Dec. 17, 1910; but from February of 1905
that part of the property was leased to Mr. Bartolomé Ferrer
(who later organized a company with Pogolotti) to construct a
brick factory. I can give you copy of said contract.

Paragraph 53: The limekilnns and a stone quarry were operated
from the year 1857 with negro slaves and Chinese, various persons
being lessees during the course of the years, the last being Sr.
Calleja and Brother, who leased same, together with the residence,
to July 31, 1900. When these gentlemen ceased being lessees and
the house was vacant, the family moved in for the first time.
(July 1900).

The quarry was not operated from that date until April 1907
when it was leased to Mr. Demetrio Zunzunegui. The contract stated:
Land occupied by the quarries now open, the kilns and the well,
which is approximately 4 to 6 acres. Also, the contract states:
The lessee may occupy the two small wooden houses which are located
close to the kilns, etc. I can furnish you with this contract.

Paragraphs 54 to 62: The property San José was owned by
the Pedroso family from the middle of the XVIII century. Mrs. Rojas
was married the first time to her cousin, Mr. Martin Javier Pedroso,
who inherited same from his great grandfather the Count of Casa
Pedroso y Garro. Both the residence as well as the fence in front
existed already in 1857. Said fence is of masonry, a mixture much
used formerly, composed of rock of all sizes, earth and clay,
covered with adobe. All the front had this fence, on the sides
and back the fence was of stone as shown on the plan of 1907. When
the property was sold the sides were provisionally fenced with
wire, the present fence, which is of brick, being constructed in
1930. Then the old wall in front was reinforced with some pillars
and covered with a new coat (of cement.) (Translator's note: The
Spanish text simply states a new coat was given so it is not clear
whether adobe or cement - customarily used in this country - was
used. I imagine you saw the wall and know what it is.)

Paragraph 54 and 55: It appears that the Camp had no fence
of any kind.

Sra. Dolores Morales is 60 years old and was some 20 years
old when she came to live at the property for the first time in July
1900.

Her brother, Sr. Ygnacio Morales was then 10 years old and
only remembers the express detail of what he was given to feed his
little pig. He does not remember there being any fence.

The sister of Sra. Morales who is ill is named Señorita Josefita
-2-
Morales and lives in the house on the corner, not in the Finca.
Paragraph 61: The date of the old map is 1857.

Paragraphs 59 to 67: Calzada de Maximo Gomez is the modern
(present) name of the Calzada from Marianao to Cerro, but no one
uses it and continues to call it by the old names.

The name “Loma Llaves” is that given to the Reparto (Sub-divi-
sion) when buildings were constructed on the lands of the property
San Francisco Javier, which borders the property San José.

Having clarified the matter of the small houses, it can be
presumed that the wooden floors, which both Sra. Rojas and Sra.
Morales remember, belonged to the tents. They cannot recall
having used same for anything nor what was done with them.
Photo 17 e: Shows the stone quarry belonging to the property.

Photo 16 a and b: The limekiln which was not operated at
that time. It is not known what the wooden houses at the side of
the tents were.

We have never owned property (finca - farm) in the vicinity
of Camp Columbia other than this (San Jose.).

You may have at your disposal the bark of all the trees on
my property.

Regarding the reason why there is no tradition among the
present inhabitants concerning Camp Lazear, this is due to the
fact that all this land was unoccupied until many years later.
At that time the property was occupied only by the family, the
lessee, Mr. Antonio Sosa (now dead) and the laborers who cultivated
the land. Nevertheless, Mr. Zunzunegui, who leased the limekilns
six years later, recalls the story.

The belief and remembrance of Sra. Rojas that the land of
the property was ceded to the American Government is due to the
fact that this was the desire of Dr. Rojas, but according to the
entries in the books, the lands of the property were leased to
Mr. Antonio Sosa, who cultivated same, planting small crops, and
they could not have been ceded. Thus a modest rent was collected,
of which the lessee received half.
(Mr. Moran has seen this book)

Nov. 15, 1900: Today for the third time the Military Health
Officers of the American Army entered the property San Jose in
agreement with the lessee Don Antonio Sosa and through mediation
of Dr. Echevarria.

January 2, 1901: Collected the check sent by the Surgeon
Major of the U.S.A., Mr. Reed, value $20.00, covering the first
month's rent on the land of the San Jose property occupied by
the experimental Commission of Yellow Fever. Of this amount one-
half delivered to Mr. Antonio Sosa, Lessee of said lands.

January 19, 1901: Major J. R. Kean, Surgeon U.S.A. paid
$20., American gold, amount of the second month's rent on land
of the property San José occupied by the Yellow Fever Experimental
Commission, from Dec. 10, 1900 to January 9, 1901.

February 25, 1901: Major J. R. Kean, U.S.A. Surgeon, Dis-
bursing Officer, Columbia Barracks, sent check for $40.00 American
gold covering two months rent on land of the Property San Jose
in Marianao occupied by the Yellow Fever Experimentation, covering
rent from January 10th to March 9th, at the rate of $20. American
gold per month. Half for Sosa.

April 22, 1901: Major J. R. Kean Surgeon, U.S. Army Disbursing
Officer today sent the vouchers to sign covering payment of the
rent on Camp Lazear, March 9th to May 10th, located on the property
San Jose, Marianao.

June 11, 1901: Collected from Major J. R. Kean Surgeon, U.S.
Army Disbursing Officer the amount of rent on lands occupied by
Camp Lazear on the property San José covering period from May 9th
to July 10th of this year - $40.00 American gold, that is, $44.00
Spanish.

September 29, 1901: Today I returned the signed vouchers to
Major J. R. Kean Surgeon, U.S.A. Disbursing Officer, covering
two months rent on the land occupied by Camp Lazear Experimental
Sanitary Camp on the property San José, which came due on August
10th and September 9th, at the rate of $20., American gold, per
month - $40.00 gold.

October 1 10, 1901: Today I received the last check for $20.00
covering rent on Camp Lazear located on the property San Jose,
up to the 9th and they left the land; delivering the two wooden
houses which they constructed to carry out experiments on yellow
fever and mosquitoes.

I believe that the place to mark on the map as the site of
Camp Lazear is that shown on the Plan of 1907 by limekilns

1. Because in the photographs of Camp Lazear the old lime-
kilns can be seen.

2. Because as the two wooden houses were not torn down when
the Camp was broken up, as shown in the entry in the Note Book,
these were the two wooden houses, next to the limekilns, mentioned
in the lease contract to Mr. Zunzunegui in 1907, and which are not
mentioned in previous leases of limekilns. Another significant
detail of this contract is that it gives the measurement of the
land in acres, which is not used in Cuba and is used in the United
States...

The statements of Mr. Zunzunegui, to which little importance
were at first attached, may now have value. Mr. Moran interviewed
him.

Paragraph 54: The following is correct: When Calzada
Columbia crosses Avenida Buen Retiro one turns left (southeast)
until Avenida Buen Retiro runs into the Calzada de Marianao.
The latter is the old main road between Quemados, Marianao and
Havana and is variously called Calzada Real de Marianao, Calzada
Real, Real St. in Marianao and Calzada de Marianao. Now: Turning
to the left in the direction of Havana, you come to the property
“Finca San Jose” at the right and between the streets Villalón and
José Miguel Gomez. A little farther on and also on the right is
a brickyard (Tejar).
